questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with unilateral hearing loss. The audiogram is shown above. Which sign is most likely to be present in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hitzelberger sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the audiometric pattern of acoustic neuroma (gradual high-frequency SNHL) and its associated clinical sign (Hitzelberger sign) is crucial for diagnosis. The lack of air-bone gap differentiates it from otosclerosis.

questions.text: What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • 🔍 Explanation of Options:
  • • Option A: Grade 1
  • • Option A: Grade 1
  • • In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.
  • • In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.
  • • Option B: Grade 2
  • • Option B: Grade 2
  • • Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.
  • • Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.
  • • Option C: Grade 3
  • • Option C: Grade 3
  • • In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.
  • • In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.
  • • Option D: Grade 4
  • • Option D: Grade 4
  • • This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.
  • • This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ 🧠 Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.
  • ➤ Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. His CT scan is given. What could be the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with symptoms including nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. The CT scan shows a mass involving the maxillary sinus. These clinical features are highly suggestive of maxillary sinus carcinoma. This condition often presents with such symptoms due to the tumor mass causing obstruction and local invasion.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: This condition typically occurs in adolescent males and arises from the nasopharynx, not the maxillary sinus. It is characterized by severe epistaxis and nasal obstruction, but the patient's age and the location of the mass make this diagnosis unlikely.
  • • Option A. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma:
  • • Option C. Orbital Floor Fracture: Orbital floor fractures are best seen in coronal CT views and typically result from trauma. They present with symptoms such as diplopia, enophthalmos, and infraorbital anesthesia, but not with nasal obstruction and cheek swelling without trauma history.
  • • Option C. Orbital Floor Fracture:
  • • Option D. Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis: This condition is seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. It involves rapid tissue destruction, including the eyes and palate, leading to black necrotic tissue. The presentation of the patient does not fit this severe and aggressive infection.
  • • Option D. Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maxillary sinus carcinoma presents with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. Diagnosis is often confirmed through imaging, showing a mass in the maxillary sinus

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. On otoscopic examination, a reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. CT scan shows an enhancing mass with intact caroticojugular spine, and the lesion appears to be confined to the mesotympanum. (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glomus tympanicum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To differentiate between glomus tympanicum and jugulare based on the integrity of the caroticojugular spine (felp sign) and extent of tumor, which guides surgical approach and prognosis.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

questions.text: A patient presents with foul-smell from nose and nasal obstruction. The image of the finding is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atrophic rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical presentation of Atrophic Rhinitis is crucial, especially the distinctive symptoms of nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge, along with visible crusting as seen in the provided image. This helps differentiate it from other forms of rhinitis, which do not present with such severe crusting or malodour.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: A child was brought to OPD with cola colored urine, his mother gives history of odynophagia, dysphagia, fever, and membrane over tonsils as given in image. Which among the following is likely cause? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Streptococcal Tonsillitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Streptococcal tonsillitis is characterized by a tenacious exudate that forms a membrane over the tonsils. The image shows a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, which is typical for streptococcal tonsillitis. This condition can present with symptoms such as fever, odynophagia (painful swallowing), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), and cola-colored urine (a sign of possible post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A . Faucial diphtheria: Presents with a thick, grayish membrane that bleeds when removed. It is typically accompanied by significant cervical lymphadenopathy and neck swelling, which is not described in the case.
  • • Option A
  • • Faucial diphtheria:
  • • Option B . Vincent angina: Also known as acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis, is associated with ulcerations and necrotic areas rather than forming a thick membrane over the tonsils. The description and image do not match this presentation.
  • • Option B
  • • Vincent angina:
  • • Option D . Oral Candidiasis: Generally presents with widespread white plaques that can be scraped off, revealing red, inflamed tissue underneath. The membrane shown in the image is more localized to the tonsils, which is more characteristic of streptococcal tonsillitis.
  • • Option D
  • • Oral Candidiasis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Streptococcal tonsillitis can present with a thick, white exudate covering the tonsils, accompanied by fever, painful swallowing, and potential complications such as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, indicated by cola-colored urine.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with his mother, who is concerned about his nasal-sounding voice. She reports that her son seems to be frequently "talking through his nose," especially when he is trying to pronounce 'm' and 'n' sounds. Additionally, she mentions that he breathes through his mouth most of the time, especially at night, and has been having difficulty sleeping. On examination, the boy has no signs of acute respiratory distress but does have a hyponasal voice. Xray reveals enlarged adenoids obstructing the nasopharynx. No other abnormalities are noted. What type of voice change is most likely present in this patient due to his enlarged adenoids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinorrhea clausa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The voice of a patient with enlarged adenoids is likely to exhibit Rhinolalia clausa, characterized by a nasal quality due to obstruction of the nasal passages.

questions.text: A nasal endoscopy image shows a septal perforation in a patient following nasal surgery done 3 months ago. Preoperative CT scan showed extensive bilateral concha bullosa which was addressed surgically. Which surgery is the most likely cause of this perforation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) FESS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During FESS for bilateral concha bullosa, careful surgical technique is essential as aggressive resection or poor visualization can lead to septal damage and subsequent perforation, particularly when operating on both sides of the nasal cavity

questions.text: A 14-year-old male is brought to OPD with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. On examination, a mass was observed on left posterior choanae as shown below. What is the management of the patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Surgical excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected JNA, especially with the classical presentation of recurrent nosebleeds in adolescent males, prompt referral for imaging and surgical consultation is critical. Surgical excision, following detailed imaging and possibly preoperative embolization, represents the best approach to manage this condition effectively.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and bleeding. After diagnosis, it is determined to be inverted papilloma. What is the correct description of this diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Benign and locally invasive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally invasive tumor primarily affecting the nasal cavity, requiring aggressive surgical management due to its invasive characteristics and potential complications. Regular follow-up is crucial due to the risk of recurrence and rare malignant transformation.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic otitis media presents with hearing loss. On otoscopic examination, there is significant tympanosclerosis with calcific plaques but no perforation. During evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What would be the expected outcome of the Rinne test? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Positive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tympanosclerosis without perforation typically causes mild conductive hearing loss with an air-bone gap less than 30 dB, resulting in a positive Rinne test, unlike tympanic membrane perforation which causes a negative Rinne test due to more significant conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with diabetes arrived at the clinic with a concerning issue - a black, malodorous discharge originating from her nose. Upon examination, it was discovered that the nasal cavity contained a dark necrotic mass, which had caused erosion of both the septum and hard palate. What could be the most likely diagnosis for this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mucormycosis should be considered a medical emergency in immunocompromised patients presenting with signs of rapid, invasive sinus infection. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial to improve survival rates in affected individuals.

questions.text: Foreign body entry into the laryngeal inlet is prevented by the cough reflex. This reflex is sluggish in alcohol ingestion and some other conditions. Which nerve is likely injured? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Internal laryngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to or inhibition of the internal laryngeal nerve can significantly impair the cough reflex by reducing the sensory input required to detect irritants above the vocal cords, emphasizing its pivotal role in this protective reflex.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 337

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases

options.label: D
options.text: It shows Ad type of curve

questions.correct_answer: D. It shows Ad type of curve
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given endoscopic view of the nasal cavity:( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inferior turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior turbinate is a critical structure for the proper conditioning of air entering the respiratory system. Its large surface area and vascular mucosa play essential roles in the humidification and warming of inhaled air, contributing to the overall respiratory health and protection against pathogens and particulate matter.

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trotter’s method

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trotter’s method is an effective first-line intervention for controlling epistaxis. It emphasizes maintaining an upright, forward-leaning posture to minimize blood swallowing and facilitate proper drainage, essential for patient comfort and safety during a nosebleed episode.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 183, 199
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 183, 199

questions.text: The provided picture shows a patient who has undergone mastoidectomy. Identify the lateral semicircular canal in the image. ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral semicircular canal, identified at label A, is part of the vestibular system, crucial for balance and orientation.

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the diagnostic maneuver?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes. The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.
  • ➤ The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes.
  • ➤ Dix-Hallpike maneuver
  • ➤ The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.
  • ➤ Epley's maneuver
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 47
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 47

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 209
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stage IB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ THE RADKOWSKI STAGING SYSTEM FOR JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA
  • ➤ THE RADKOWSKI STAGING SYSTEM FOR JUVENILE NASOPHARYNGEAL ANGIOFIBROMA

questions.text: Water's view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Water's view is particularly effective for visualizing the maxillary sinus, making it an essential diagnostic tool in sinus imaging, especially when evaluating issues related to the maxillary sinuses.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 493
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: A patient presents with a firm, tender, slow-growing mass below the ear as shown in the image below. What could be the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parotid abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnosing and treating a parotid abscess promptly is crucial to prevent further complications such as the spread of infection. The characteristic presentation of swelling, tenderness, and systemic signs in a specific location aids in differential diagnosis from other potential conditions affecting the neck and jaw area.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition pg 297
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition pg 297

questions.text: A child was brought to ENT OPD with complaints of mouth breathing and snoring from a long duration. He also asks to increase the volume of TV while watching. What is the best treatment for this child’s condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenoidectomy and grommet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of chronic adenoid hypertrophy causing mouth breathing, snoring, and conductive hearing loss, the best treatment involves adenoidectomy along with the insertion of a grommet to ensure proper drainage of middle ear fluid and restore normal hearing.

questions.text: For newborn hearing screening purpose, which test is most commonly used? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) OAE

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE) testing is the standard and most commonly used initial screening method for detecting hearing loss in newborns due to its simplicity, quick results, and effectiveness.

questions.text: Mark the correct description for laryngeal cancer stage T1b N0 M0.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Vocal cords involved and fixed

options.label: B
options.text: Both Vocal cords involved and mobile

options.label: C
options.text: One Vocal cord involved and fixed

options.label: D
options.text: One Vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.correct_answer: B. Both Vocal cords involved and mobile
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Both vocal cords involved and mobile

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TNM staging for CA Larynx:
  • ➤ TNM staging for CA Larynx:
  • ➤ T1 – only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis) T2 – involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility . T3 – involving pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords . T4a – local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc) N0 – no cervical lymph nodes N1 – single ipsilateral < 3cm N2 – single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm N3 – single or multiple nodes > 6cm M0 – no metastasis M1 – metastasis present
  • ➤ T1 – only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)
  • ➤ T2 – involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility .
  • ➤ impaired vocal cord mobility
  • ➤ T3 – involving pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords .
  • ➤ fixed vocal cords
  • ➤ T4a – local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx
  • ➤ local invasion
  • ➤ T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)
  • ➤ N0 – no cervical lymph nodes
  • ➤ N1 – single ipsilateral < 3cm
  • ➤ N2 – single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm
  • ➤ N3 – single or multiple nodes > 6cm
  • ➤ M0 – no metastasis
  • ➤ M1 – metastasis present

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 172, 173
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 172, 173

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with left-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis. On examination, a vascular mass is seen filling the left nasal cavity. CT shows a mass extending to the nasopharynx with anterior bowing of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus (Holman-Miller sign). The surgical approach shown in the image would be most appropriate for: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Midfacial degloving

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To recognize that while similar incisions may be used in different approaches, the complete surgical approach is chosen based on the pathology's extent and location. Midfacial degloving combines cosmetically favorable incisions with excellent exposure for nasopharyngeal tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used if otoacoustic emissions is absent for screening? (INICET NOV 2022) Pure tone audiometry Tympanometry Free field audiometry Speech audiometry
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 2 and 4

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? ( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 367
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with dysarthria, deviation of uvula, and difficulty swallowing liquids. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vagus nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the clinical features of vagal nerve palsy is crucial as it can be a presentation of various conditions including diabetic neuropathy, skull base tumors, or brainstem pathology. The key diagnostic features are uvular deviation, palatal weakness, and dysphagia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is: ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Respiratory papillomatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis should be considered in young children presenting with a gradual worsening of hoarseness and the development of respiratory symptoms. The condition highlights the need for awareness of HPV-related diseases in children and indicates the importance of early and accurate diagnosis followed by appropriate surgical intervention, which may include cold steel, coblation, debrider, radiofrequency, or laser-assisted microlaryngeal surgery to manage the growth and recurrence of papillomas effectively.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition pg 327, 328, 343, 345, 346
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition pg 327, 328, 343, 345, 346

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:
  • ➤ TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:
  • ➤ T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)
  • ➤ T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility .
  • ➤ impaired vocal cord mobility
  • ➤ T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords .
  • ➤ fixed vocal cords
  • ➤ T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx
  • ➤ Local invasion
  • ➤ T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)
  • ➤ N0 – No cervical lymph nodes
  • ➤ N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm
  • ➤ N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm
  • ➤ N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm
  • ➤ M0 – No metastasis
  • ➤ M1 – Metastasis present
  • ➤ Ref: Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 348
  • ➤ Ref: Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: A post-COVID patient who received prolonged steroid therapy presents with orbital pain, proptosis, and decreased vision. Which investigation would confirm the diagnosis in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-COVID patients with orbital symptoms, early diagnosis of invasive fungal infection is crucial. While both Aspergillus and Mucor can cause similar presentations, MRI characteristics can help differentiate between them and guide appropriate antifungal therapy. The key is recognizing specific imaging patterns that suggest fungal invasion before extensive tissue damage occurs

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient arrives at the OPD with a concern about her ability to perceive speech sounds while struggling to comprehend the actual words being spoken. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) and Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results show discrepancies, as the PTA is relatively within the normal range. However, her mid-latency and cortical responses are both non-existent. What probable diagnosis can be inferred from these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auditory neuropathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Auditory neuropathy should be suspected in patients who present with normal hearing sensitivity on pure tone audiometry but show significant difficulties with speech comprehension and abnormal brainstem evoked response audiometry results.

questions.text: Identify the blocked structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maxillary sinus can be blocked by an antrochoanal polyp that extends into the nasal cavity through the middle meatus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

questions.text: A patient presents with a fluctuant, tender swelling below the mastoid tip extending into the upper neck as shown in the image. What could be the diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bezold abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomical pathway of Bezold's abscess is crucial for diagnosis. Pus breaking through the mastoid tip follows a specific path along muscle planes, creating a characteristic clinical picture. Early recognition is important as it requires both mastoid surgery and neck exploration for adequate drainage

questions.text: Which of these labeled structures represents a division of the internal carotid artery? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vascular Supply of the Nasal Cavity:
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 198
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 198

questions.text: A 35-year-old scuba diver presents with ear fullness and hearing loss immediately after surfacing. The otoscopic finding is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pneumotympanum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the pathophysiology and otoscopic findings of middle ear barotrauma, a condition caused by pressure changes during activities like scuba diving. Learn to recognize symptoms such as ear fullness, hearing loss, and hemorrhage behind the tympanic membrane, and differentiate it from similar conditions. Focus on prevention, symptomatic management, and when to seek specialized care.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for JNA? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CECT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The investigation of choice for diagnosing Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is CECT due to its ability to define the tumor's vascularity and extent while safely avoiding the complications associated with biopsy

questions.text: Which perspective provides the clearest view of the frontal sinus? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Caldwell’s view

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stenver’s view is done for cochlear implants.
  • ➤ Stenver’s view is done for cochlear implants.
  • ➤ Law’s view is used to assess mastoid air cells.
  • ➤ Law’s view is used to assess mastoid air cells.

References:

  • ↳ Reference – Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 493, 494

questions.text: An adult patient presents with acute respiratory distress during dinner. They are unable to speak but can cough weakly. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Back blows

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the stepwise approach to foreign body airway obstruction is crucial. Current guidelines emphasize starting with back blows in partial obstruction with ineffective cough, progressing to abdominal thrusts only if back blows are unsuccessful. This approach maximizes effectiveness while minimizing the risk of complications.

questions.text: Pott's puffy tumor is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.correct_answer: A. Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pott's puffy tumor is a severe and rare complication of frontal sinusitis, presenting with distinctive forehead swelling and potentially grave complications. Prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment are crucial to prevent further spread of infection and ensure recovery.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 224
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 224

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. A histology image is shown below. What can be the diagnosis for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schwannoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwannoma is a benign tumor often associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, diagnosed via characteristic histological patterns and confirmed with MRI. It requires careful management, sometimes involving advanced surgical techniques such as Gamma Knife surgery.

questions.text: A child presents with foul-smelling ear discharge. On further exploration, a small perforation is found in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane as shown below. Most appropriate management would be: (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: IV antibiotics and follow up after a month

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Attico-antral CSOM, characterized by foul-smelling discharge and attic perforation, requires tympanomastoid exploration for definitive management.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mollison's mastoid retractor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mollison's Mastoid retractor is specifically tailored for ear surgeries, particularly mastoidectomy, where precise and sustained retraction of soft tissues is crucial. Understanding the specific applications and features of various retractors enhances surgical efficiency and safety.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Earache

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: What are Kraissl’s lines? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture

options.label: C
options.text: Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.correct_answer: B. Relaxed tension lines in skin
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Relaxed tension lines in skin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kraissl’s lines are crucial for surgical incision planning to ensure scars are minimally visible following healing, highlighting the importance of understanding skin tension dynamics in medical procedures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old individual with diabetes presented with intense ear pain and otorrhea that did not improve with antibiotics. During the examination, granulation tissue was observed in the external auditory canal (EAC), and the person also exhibited facial nerve palsy. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Malignant otitis externa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa is a critical condition requiring aggressive management due to its potential to cause widespread damage and severe complications, including cranial nerve involvement. Prompt and appropriate treatment is essential to prevent potentially life-threatening outcomes.

References:

  • ↳ Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 55

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge along with the following CT scan. On suction cleaning, there is thick mucin that contains eosinophils, Charcot-Leyden crystals. What would be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Allergic fungal sinusitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge. The presence of thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, as well as the CT findings, are indicative of allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS). AFS is characterized by the accumulation of eosinophils and allergic mucin in the sinuses, often resulting in hyperdensities on CT scans.
  • • Treatment is always surgical exploration (removal of fungal mass)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fungal Ball: A fungal ball, or mycetoma, typically involves a single sinus (commonly the maxillary sinus) and appears as a mass of fungal elements without significant allergic mucin or eosinophils. It does not usually present with eosinophils or Charcot-Leyden crystals in the discharge.
  • • Option A. Fungal Ball:
  • • Option C. Chronic rhinosinusitis: Chronic rhinosinusitis involves prolonged inflammation of the sinuses but does not specifically present with the eosinophilic mucin and Charcot-Leyden crystals seen in AFS. The CT findings in chronic rhinosinusitis do not typically show the hyperdensities seen in AFS.
  • • Option C. Chronic rhinosinusitis:
  • • Option D. Fulminant fungal sinusitis: Fulminant fungal sinusitis is a rapidly progressive infection seen in immunocompromised patients and involves extensive bony destruction and tissue invasion. The CT scan would show significant bone destruction and possibly extension into adjacent structures, which is not evident in this case.
  • • Option D. Fulminant fungal sinusitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Allergic fungal sinusitis is characterized by unilateral nasal obstruction, thick mucin containing eosinophils and Charcot-Leyden crystals, and hyperdensities on CT scans, without extensive bony destruction.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Left hypoactive labyrinth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The direction of the slow and fast components of nystagmus is crucial in diagnosing the affected side in vestibular disorders. A left hypoactive labyrinth leads to nystagmus with a fast component to the right, matching the clinical presentation in this scenario.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 43
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 43

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.
